The bar melds perfectly inside the restaurant and does not make you feel like it is the "bar" area. Tables fill this room for dining or having a cocktail. One step up and to the side is an elevated floor, where we sat.  Beyond the "bar" area that you walk into, is a more secluded dining area, but we were center stage and had a great view of it all. 

Hubby and I ordered and shared three appetizers. We loved them all, but I was partial to the escargot and the oysters Rockefeller and he to the clams casino, so I did not mind letting him finish the clams while I devoured the other two appetzers. We did skip salads, but hubby enjoyed the wonderful lobster bisque, of which I found exceptionally good, with my one snitched spoonfull. 

My husband had the Prime Rib, what else? I love filet mignon and they have in house made bearnaise sauce, so I stuck with what I love best and it was a huge, juicy and tender portion, very good indeed. 

The restaurant has a lot of class and prices are what you would expect. 

What I loved most about the service, for such an upscale establishment, the wait staff was not at all uptight. The waiters were professional, but with charisma and humor and knew how and when to have conversation. 

Bottom line, I would go back in a heartbeat!

Wheelchair accessible with ramp through main entrance into the lobby of the hotel and entrance right in through their door.

Came to the prime rib for a dinner a few weeks ago.  I ordered the prime rib medium rare and it was delicious. It's was prepared and seasoned very well. For dessert I had the key lime pie. Their key lime pie was pretty good and not too tarty. The ambiance in this place is nice. There was a pianist to provide entertainment.

I ordered the smoked trout Benedict with potatoes and it was the worst Benedict I have ever had.  In my lifetime I have enjoyed Benedict dishes in seven U.S. states from the west coast to the east coast and Bourbon & Branch managed to really ruin a potential good meal.  The potatoes were hard as a rock, they seemed as though they had been sitting out for three days.  The trout was over-salted, the sauce had no flavor and the bread (not English muffin) was horrible.  The eggs were under-cooked and also over-salted.

I then tried my friend's hummus and pita, also quite bad.  The pita bread was wet (with water) and the hummus was flavorless AND over-salted.  I am able to prepare better hummus and pita whilst in a coma.

My husband ordered the chicken and biscuits, the bacon n'beer mac and the branch brined wings.  ALL were over-salted.  The "food" was not edible.

Burbon and Branch is apparently for people who are too drunk to notice (or care) if they have been served proper food or not.  PATHETIC.
The best chicken and biscuits I've ever had. I dream about it at night.

Not bad whiskey bar.  Some interesting cocktails, though they were all a bit sweet for my taste.  I tried the Broken Chandelier (gin, St. Germain, cilantro, cucumber, simple sugar).  It was pretty good, though I think it would have been better with Hendrick's over Bombay and if there was a bit less simple syrup.  I think the other one that I tried was the Irish Jolly (Jameson, Snap ginger liqueur, fresh black berries, lime, ginger ale).  It wasn't my favorite, I don't think I liked the Snap liqueur). 

A pretty good list of beers available.  The couple that I tried I enjoyed more than the cocktails.  A long and interesting list of whiskey.  I think next time I will be just sticking to whiskey or rye with ice.  

I like the vibe here, it seemed to be busy, bustling, without being over crowded.

I went here with some friends while visiting for the weekend, I am extremely pleased with everything about this place. From the decor, vibe, music (DJ was playing old soul music and R&B that hit every chord in the right way). The portions were grand, I feel like there are often many spots that don't get it right or overcharge for basics, not here. I loved everyone else's dishes too (literally since the place settings are a mixture of types / designs of plates). Their biscuits are SOOOOOO good, make SURE you get them. I had the cheesy grits with shrimp hands down awesome & prepared the right way (and I'm picky since I go to ATL a lot), they get it right here! Absolutely coming back here for my next brunch when I'm in town!

Wow. The food, atmosphere, and service here are all phenomenal. 

Let me start with my favorite part - the menu is pasted into children's books which is so cool! 
The atmosphere is hipsterish - dim lighting, great music, and laid back vibe. I went on a Sunday for brunch and it was not too crowded, easy to walk in and get seated without a wait. 

SO MUCH BETTER THAN GREEN EGGS in my opinion. 

After much deliberation between various items, I ordered the chicken and waffles and in the words of DJ Tanner, OH MY LANTA. The seasoning on the chicken was beyond delicious (not dry at all, which is a complaint I often have about chicken) and the waffles were crisp and perfectly done. The syrup was not too rich and sweet and you could tell it was authentic, not the sugary thick store bought stuff. 

In addition, I have to say, I found the HOLY GRAIL of biscuits. These are not your small round KFC biscuits. They are HUGE, soft, mushy, delicious, amazing. I have been craving them every day since. They have cheddar bits baked inside and when you pull these freshly baked delights apart and take a bite, I guarantee a religious experience.

If you can't tell, I loved this place.

My only complaint -  Why haven't I been here before?!

Everything about this place gets 5 stars.

Food: AMAZING. Just take a look at all of the pictures I attached, there wasn't an item on the menu that left you unsatisfied. Luckily, I went with a large party so there was plenty of opportunities to snag a bite here and there. 

Fried Pickles - crispy & delicious with a batter to pickle ratio that is on point
Oxtail fries - an explosion of flavors. Oxtail is a fattier meat, so just know that going into it!
Bang Bang Chicken Sandwich - really good! The sandwich was not what I was expecting since it came on a hoagie roll. It reminded me more of a glorified cheese steak. It was delicious, but if I come back I'll probably order something else on the menu
Kale Caesar Salad - delicious!
Chicken and Waffles - That chicken is incredible. Every bite just got better and better and it made me want to cry a little inside when it was over
Mac & Cheese - YUM
Chicken Wings - Pretty good!

Our server was Jonathan who was awesome. He made great recommendations and overall made it a fun experience for all of us. Service was incredibly attentive and the entire evening was so smooth. The atmosphere of this place is also great. The music put me in an awesome mood and really contributed to the entire experience. 

I HIGHLY recommend this place. I WILL BE BACK!

Not really my best experience. It was late fall so the weather was starting to get chilly. The place was cold insidea nd rather empty. We sat down I ordered a Thai Tea and it took forever. When the waiter dropped the tea off he didn't take the order he just headed back to the kitchen area. So now we are waiting, and waiting.......tick tock...tick, tick, tick, tock.....

Finally ahh success -- we order yellow curry with chicken and pad thai with shrimp. When the items arrived the curry looked on point. But the pad thai looked --eh, not good. The shrimp had a funny color, the noodles looked soft and mushy, any way the meal was really just a 2.5 but I gave it a three b/c a 2 is kinda low and well everyone has a bad day.

After seeing Mark P's picture & review of the spicy tom yum noodle soup w/ seafood, I knew I had to get me some of that ASAFP.

Well I can say it lived up to the hype, and thensome! It came in huge pho-sized bowl, steaming with an amazing aroma with lots of shrimp peeking out.  Along with the generous amount nice-sized shrimps, there were also mussels, scallops, and squid, about 4-5 pieces of each.  And then the broth, oh my god, this broth.  Perfectly spiced, tangy, savory...just freaking amazing.  Best $12 I've ever spent.

I'd suggest you go alone when you get this, so you can just focus on the flavors and moan with pleasure without judgment or distraction.  This soup commands your full undivided attention.

Mark P, I owe ya one!

This was my first time here. I was very pleasantly surprised by how good the food is. I had not seen any Yelp reviews but saw some other reviews. People swore this was the best Chinese food they have had outside of major cities like Manhattan. They were right. While I was eating a guy came in and said to the clerk that they have the best Sweet and Sour soup. I will have to try that now. I had the beef chow mein. It was the best I have had at any Chinese restaurant!!! The beef was nice and tender. My meal came with fried rice (no pork) and tasted great. Very friendly family folk working there. I will come again next time I am in the mood for good Chinese food!!!!!

I really love Angela - the owner of the new Wings to Go on the Corner of Vine & 15th.

So, I ordered a bunch of party platters (boneless wings & buffalo shrimp) for a party I had.  Everything was piping hot, fresh and perfect.

I really want people to support this much needed busines on an otherwise "dead" block.  Need wings?  Catfish?  Shrimp?  Corndogs?  Come here to get them.

So glad that Angela and the gang are still going strong after 2 years, delivering wings, ribs, corn dogs and FABULOUS fried shrimp to Drexel/Hahnemann students and others.

Wednesday is 1/2 price boneless wings and Monday is the Shrimp deal.

Love to take my 6 year old here - as I, probably should not even contemplate eating this.  It's an OCCAISIONAL treat only.  And we get celery in lieu of fries - and I get a salad - so I feel a little less guilty.

Bring on the fried shrimp!
And corn dogs. (Big and slightly sweet batter.)  Umm!

Interesting location considering Chipotle and Moe's are so close by.

I walked in and didn't really know what to do. No one yelled "WELCOME to The Lime!" and there was no one else jn line in front of me for me to follow their lead and eavesdrop on their order. 

Why was  I a little flustered upon walking in? Their menu is not very user friendly. My main issue was the disturbingly low occurrence of guacamole on it. I scanned the menu for something with guacamole on it, as I wanted whatever that would be (avocados being present on a menu item is usually how I decide what I'm going to pick). Nothing seemed to come with guac. Could I add guac to my meal? I had no idea how much it would cost since there was no mention of add ons, so I refrained. Perhaps it would have given my naked beef burrito (everything but the tortilla) some more flair. 

Another gripe about the menu: be clear if "beef" means ground beef or steak. They had delicious looking steak cooking on the grill which is why I chose beef for my meal. I was pretty disappointed it ended up being ground beef.

They DO get major points for their salsa bar, which in addition to about 8 different salsas includes fresh cilantro. I'm a huge salsa verde fan, and theirs was pretty on point. 

Overall, this is a middle-of-the-road casual Mexican joint on par with Tijuana Flats or Moe's. I will give it another try but I'll probably go for a quesadilla or tacos since my burrito bowl didn't leave much of an impression.

Stopped in here after leaving the airport and the line was out the door, welcome to lunch time. The line dissipated quickly and before you know it we were sitting at our table. The tortilla soup  was delicious, loaded with chicken, the taste was amazing. I went with a "naked" burrito, welcome to diet week. The salsa and hot sauce bar is worth the trip alone, but the food does kick it up a notch.

Sometimes there's lively service, but this time our order was taken by a timid individual that never even greeted us. We just received a look upon approaching the register. We chose to order our Cali Burritos as bowls (love that option!) The Big Cali Bowl was full of fresh ingredients, despite them forgetting Guacamole in mine :( Oh yes, I went to the counter and asked for it, wouldnt you? No biggie, a server brought it out soon after and the feast began. Yes, I do mean feast! The bowls are huge and I can eat a lot! The cilantro-lime rice was cooked well and the tortillas fresh crunch compliment the other textures in the bowl. I didnt get any of the hot sauces (15+ to choose from), but theres no shortage. If Taco Bell is your thing, you need to step up your game!

Excellent food, inconsistent service, creative atmosphere, and cool seating options.

Will return.

Lime Fresh Mexican Grill, not to be confused with the Green Lemon, formerly known as the Lime, has the best salsa bar! I was a little worried when we got here because the line was out the door.  However I was impressed at how quickly we were able to place our order. They let us pick out our salsas and take a seat and brought us the food when it was ready which is better service than chipotle. I got the grilled fish tacos for $8 which Chipotle and Moes does not offer and they were very good.  My other buddies got a steak queaadilla for $8, chicken burrito for $7, and taco salad for $7 and everyone enjoyed their meals.  They give you plenty of chips and salsas to go with your meal! They do have excellent frozen Margaritas here and offer a 2 for 1 happy hour Wed Thurs Fri 2PM-7PM, including $2 tacos! They give you a lot of food. Value 9/10, Parking 10/10, Sevice is not full so 6/10, decor 7/10 nothing special but not bad either, Food 8/10 stay away from the hard shell tacos according to other reviews.  Better than Moes and Chipotle but about the same as Tijuana Flats. This place gets the edge because of a huge selection of salsas and sauces though! Will be back again soon! :)

The "I Wanna Tijuana Taco" is a corn tortilla wrapped in soft flour tortilla filled & well balanced with choice of protein, lettuce, tomato, sour cream, and cheese! Perfectly crafted and "user friendly!" 

The Avocado Bacon Quesadilla with chicken is loaded, and with a creamy cilantro sauce which will win over cilantro haters! The chicken and ground beef fillings have great mexican flavor! 

These two choices with their Burritos are served with "bottomless fresh tortilla chips!" 
Need Salsa? Their salsa bar is killer! My faves include pineapple, verde, and acho salsas! 

Their desserts include Cinnamon Chips, Key Lime Pie, and my choice, Sopapilla, with powdered sugar & a side of agave nectar!

Do ya think I became a fan on my first visit? Simply put, "Sí, mucho!"

In lieu of 4th of July, we decided to nix the burgers and dogs and give Palace of Asia a shot. We had heard from various people that Palace was the real deal. Our host graciously seated us and asked if we would be ordering from the menu or eating the buffet. Buffet you say? I must also mention that this was my first Indian dining experience. We opted for the buffet, so we could sample a little bit of everything. Wow, was it good! I cannot pronounce nor will I embarrass myself by trying to spell the names of the dishes I tried, but I can tell you that the lamb was among one of my favorites. Yogurt dipping sauces were also very good. Our server also provided us with steaming, hot naan which was very good. For $10, I definitely plan on returning and I suggest you do the same.

There was certainly  no shortage of things to see on this tour . . .sadly none of them were alligators as the water was still too cold for them to be frolicking about.  And if you have your heart set on seeing and touching a baby alligator like they show on their website, you may also be disappointed as there are not enough for all the boats to have one.  Some people on our tour (from Australia, no less) had their hearts set on it and the tour guide acted like he didn't know what they were talking about!

The tour itself, was fun.  A couple of hours in the sunshine on a boat?  What could be wrong with that?  And we did see a few turtles, an egret and 3 snakes (not the highlight of my trip, I must add)  And it was too early in the season for mosquitoes too so that was a win!

But it was so busy back on the bayou that we had to keep backing up to let other boats pass and the quantity of marshmallows that were floating in the water made me wonder why they were pitching marshmallows at the alligators- last I checked meat would have been a better idea but maybe the economy hit the alligator feeding too!

The $49 tour ($43 if you book it on line) will get you picked up at your hotel in their bus and admission to the boat tour.  If you have your own car- it's only $25.  If I had to do it again- I'd probably rent a car just so I didn't have to hear the crazy tour that the bus driver gave us on the 45 minute drive to the swamps.

He kept talking and offering up things like "Katrina . . . . .as seen on CNN, and the weather channel, this is the bridge that people were walking on . . .as seen on CNN"  or having us note the large amount of closed car dealerships that were closed around the route (I can show him a similar amount of closed dealerships in most states that didn't have a Hurricane).  But the real irritant was as we were driving along the interstate- he would suddenly swerve over to the side of the road and stop to show us some water where he would say, "See . . . .no one is reck-creating today as there are gators in those waters"  Urrgh.  After 45 minutes of this I had a headache!  And I kept thinking we were going to be rear ended on the freeway!!

And know that you go back on the bus that you came on so remember the number. So we got to spend more time with this guy.   If the "reck-creating" wasn't enough- on the way back we went by a space shuttle from the very well known launch pad in "Cape COD".  Really?  I didn't know that Provincetown was launching rockets these days!

Friendly, for sure, but I personally preferred the statically radio playing disco songs to the constant chatter of this guy.

Go for the boat ride- it's worth it and a great way to spend a sunny afternoon.  But if you take the bus- bring ear plugs.  You'll thank me later.

Cajun Encounters has excellent customer service. The staff responded to my emails within an hour of sending them and answered all of my questions each time. The company is also one of the few that are open for tours on Christmas Day. However, despite the "local flavor" of this group, be prepared for much of the same touristy feel complete with crying kids and exasperated parents. Tour groups are always kind of a crap shoot, I guess, and Cajun Encounters is no exception. 

I enjoyed the Swamp Tour a lot. Our guide had the perfect mix of wry humor, interesting facts and amusing stories. Furthermore, he was clearly passionate about what he did and loved his city, so he didn't sound like he was reciting a rehearsed script. The tour itself takes you through some beautiful passages within Honey Island Swamp. Those silver, hanging Spanish moss curtains you see in pictures? They're real. In person, they are so utterly beautiful that I would actually recommend you tour the swamps in the winter than in warmer seasons. You may not see as much wildlife (although we still managed to see (and handle) a baby alligator, 2 snakes, 4 turtles, 1 magnificent blue heron, a beaver-like creature, and a mama wild boar with her 2 piglets who swam out to our boat for 20 mins feasting on the marshmallows our guide threw), but there is no foliage to mar the beauty of all that silver.

The Plantation Tour was much less impressive. Not so much for the plantations or the guides, but rather that it was very poorly planned. We were given far too much time at Laura Plantation (about 3 hours) and far too little time at Oak Alley (about 1 hour total from disembarking to re-boarding). Personally, I was completely unimpressed with our guide at Laura (who for some reason pronounces "archives" with a hard "ch" like the herb), and do not understand why people rave about the tour here. I was ready to leave halfway through. Oak Alley on the other hand is just as majestic and beautiful in person as it is in all the postcards, and the tour guides are far more captivating. Every single person in our group was disappointed with the lack of time we had at Oak Alley.

The Cajun Encounters Swamp Tour was well worth it!! Make sure you can spare about 5 hours in total for the tour. The swamp they took us to was Honey Island, about 45 minutes away from the French Quarter area. The shuttle stops at about 3-4 other hotels and the tour itself is a little less than 2 hours, but there is still other time to factor in, including tour check-in and then waiting around again for the drop-off shuttle. 

We made a reservation for a Saturday morning pick-up, but the weather was not too favorable. They called about 45 minutes beforehand to cancel and/or push the tour for a later time, keeping in mind the anticipated weather for the rest of the day. Glad they did that because I've booked other tours that just pick up patrons and make people wait in hopes that the rain clears out. 

There are things to know about swamp tours which they tell you while you're on the boat. I wish there was a little check list beforehand. Like, we wouldn't see and big alligators in April because they're all out mating. Only smaller gators too young to mate would be in the swamp (so they were a little harder to see). And in advance, be prepared or ask around about mosquito activity. 

The boat fits in about 20 people. Try to be one of the first on the boat so that you're not hit by the water when the boat accelerates. And you're also closer to the tour guide when he feeds and attracts the gators. Our guide was Captain Mark. At times the boat ride was a little bumpy from bigger wooden logs just floating around. He did a great job navigating and telling the history of pre/post Katrina and plant biology. He's also well-trained to spot the gators, which I thought is difficult considering they were only about 3-4 feet long. 

At the end of the tour, we saw 4 little gators, 2 water snakes, a few duck eggs, and over 8 wild hogs. Didn't see any exotic birds, turtles or bears. Overall, I was quite satisfied with this excursion and the service of the driver, staff and Capt. Mark!

I would highly recommend this tour for anyone who is visiting the New Orleans area. It was one of the highlights of our trip. I especially loved our tour guide - no matter what question we threw at him, he knew the answer...we  defiantly  learned a lot!

I thought this tour was phenomenal!!! We had originally booked our swamp tour with Dr. something or other and they were horrible so we jumped ship (no pun intended) and booked with Cajun Encounters. I am so glad that we did! 

We opted to take the bus from NOLA and was glad that we did. Our driver was so-so and he attempted to give us a tour from town out to the dock but sadly it was lacking (this is why I am deducting half a star...you will see why the other half star deduction...just keep reading). I think there was a language barrier and that kind of sucked. Oh, and he was 30 minutes late. That was a little frustrating. We took the first tour so this meant I could have spent an extra 30 minutes sleeping. Boo!

Once we got there we checked in and it was rather chaotic (the other half star deduction). You walk in and see a long line for tickets. The bad thing was that it is in the center of the gift shop. That made shopping rather difficult. This is probably not a good thing for revenue. The dumb this was that there was a register in the back...which was closed! 

The tour itself was great! Our guide was friendly and very knowledgeable. I really enjoyed him. He gave us a history of the swamp and offered tons of info about the elusive gators of the bayou. We saw a number of them and even got to hold a baby. How awesome is that? Let me tell you, it was pretty darn awesome! I highly recommend that you request a covered boat. The poor people with the open boat were sweating like you couldn't believe. I thought it was very interesting that we did not encounter one mosquito! Amazing! 

Overall, I highly recommend this tour! If we travel back to NOLA we will definitely be back!

We had a nice city tour with rene.  Good to do in the rain.  Had a stop at the cemetary #3 and 53 distillary for taste and tour.  Picked up and dropped off at hotel.  54 dollars per adult. Very knowledgeable driver.  Saw garden district and treme and many city highlights including french quarter area.

Cajun Encounters ... matching tourists with gators since 19somethingsomething

They have a pickup route in NoLa so if one misses it, one can still get to a later stop and get on. Its a pretty comfortable ride to the swamp. You'll get to see (while in the shuttle bus) the abandoned Six Flags along the way.

Fair warning - BYOB. There is a little convenience shop where you pay fully for your ticket, but no booze. And the food gave some people stomach pains. But you can find various gator jerky. 

There are modular bathrooms that flush and have running water.

The swamp tour is pretty cool, you get to go under one of the lift bridges (?, they don't draw up in the middle, but lift straight up via four gears). You'll see grass lands, swamp lands, old trees, houses on stilts, and maybe some swamp folk. If you're lucky, you'll see some animals and stuff. We saw a baby gator, a big gator, a tiny raccoon, an angry raccoon, an egret, and a heron. 

It might drag on for a while so don't drink too much - you'll be dying for the bathroom. Fun! Definitely don't need to do it again.

I booked a combo plantation/swamp tour for our bachelorette party of 5, and we all had an amazing time. The swamp tour was the highlight of the bride-to-be's entire stay in New Orleans!

Customer service: 
Cajun Encounters has great customer service. Know that when you call them, you'll get to speak to a live person without having to jump through any hoops. That was my experience at least, and since I was putting a lot of money onto my credit card, I appreciated the awesome customer service that answered all my questions up front. 

Value: 
The plantation/swamp combo tour is $120/person and well worth every penny. Depending on the length of your stay in New Orleans, I would suggest buying the combo tour and splitting it over the course of two days, which they allow you to do (ex: plantations one day, swamp the next). We did both tours back to back the same day, and while it was fun, it was a LONG day (8:30am - 8:00pm). 

Shuttle:
Our shuttle guide going out to the plantations was great - she pointed out the local attractions and sights, including some damage from Hurricane Katrina, but also kept it light and fun with a few personal anecdotes. Liked her. The other shuttle driver on the way back from the swamp, however, was terrible. He went around the block several times attempting to drop a party off, and we had to run up to the front while the shuttle was in motion because he failed to call out our hotel as a stop on his route. It's listed on your paper, silly!

Plantations: 
It's not fair to review Cajun Encounters for the quality of your plantation tours (review those tour guides/businesses separately!). But our experience was so wonderful I might as well share it here. Laura & Oak Alley plantations speak for themselves. The plantations are rich with history, beauty and Southern tradition. You'll feel like you're on the set of Gone With the Wind. A few other highlights: lemon mint julep (Oak Alley) and some beautiful photo opportunities. At Oak Alley, the guides dress up in hoop skirts and you really feel like you've stepped back in time. At Laura, we had an amazing tour guide who gave us some detailed and interesting facts, including the slave codes and treatments in Louisiana vs. "the other side of the river". Very interesting. Again, the quality of your plantation tour all depends on your tour guide! :)

Swamp: 
Many of us thought that this was the highlight of our entire New Orleans trip. Captain Bishop was our guide and he was the only one with the "magic voice" that lured Big Al to eat his marshmallow/weenie on a stick! The other captains tried but to no avail - it must have been the baby talk that worked! Yes, you will be reminded of Disney's Jungle Cruise, especially with the comedy schtick - but I for one appreciated the jokes, especially the "Cajun humor" that Bishop inserted. We went at the perfect time just around sunset, so it was cool and refreshing with the Spanish moss blowing in the breeze. The swamp was actually quite beautiful in its own way. We saw gators of all ages and sizes UP CLOSE (the juveniles were much more eager to eat the marshmallows and weenies). We also saw birds and different types of foliage, etc. It's really great. To keep it from getting too slow, you'll go fast in the boat a couple times - which was a lot of fun!! My favorite part of the swamp was drifting by the little shanty homes on the bayou, where scenes from Beasts of the Southern Wild were filmed. Folks were sitting on their porches, drinking beers and waving to us - it was kind of awesome. After all living on the swamp, to them, is just daily life. Crazy to believe until you see it.

BRING: Bug spray, sunscreen, dollar bills for tipping, your camera :)

Overall thanks for the good time, Cajun Encounters - you made our trip wonderful!

LOVED IT!!!!!

From the reviews below, your first huge tip? Drive out to the location - that'll save you having the shuttle issues that everyone below seems to have! 

We opted for the night-time tour as we had to head to Baton Rouge the next morning, but we really wanted to fit it in.  I was dying to hold a baby alligator, but I didn't get to, though I didn't really miss it either.

The night-time tour was two hours, and no amount of bug spray (oh yeah, bring bug spray) will save you from the skeeters.  You will see the occasional spider and roach on the boat as well.  It's a freakin' night time tour in to the swamp, so if you don't expect bugs and bites, you're an idiot! (There was a chick on our boat who shrieked every ten seconds!)

Our captain, Bishop was great, he was entertaining, informative and he knew exactly what to do to to get the alligators to show themselves!  We saw a LOT of gators, a bunch of adult/full size and some littler ones too.

It was definitely a highlight of our trip to NOLA and I can't recommend it highly enough!!

It was a good experience. We were looking for something to do in New Orleans on short notice. We saw this on Yelp and I decided to call to see if they had any available slots.

I called for five adults and it was about twenty-five if you didn't need a shuttle. We took the shuttle and it was fifty-two. I am glad we took it as it was about 45 mins away. They said we could get picked up at the Best Western Landmark which was close to us. They said it would be from 8-8:30a for our pick-up.

When they say between 8-8:30a pickup, be there before 8a! Our bus driver was oh so somewhat friendly. It must be to early for her on a Friday morning...lol  She called me about 6 min before 8am that they were there already. Good thing our place was only 6 min walk. We got there at 8am and we left as were the only ones to be picked up at that location. We were dropped off at another bus. The new bus driver was very entertaining and gave us a good history from surrounding New Orleans spots on the way to the swamp.

You have to check in so go there right away. They do offer bathrooms before going on the boat. The boat ride is about an hour and a half. I recommend to bring some snacks or water if you want something to eat. I am glad that the boat has a tent to cover us from the sun. For the ladies, put your hair up as during period of times during the ride, the guide will speed up the boat. Make sure to bring your cameras as there are many spots to take photos.

Our tour guide was oh so entertaining. He was not lively in entertaining the many people on our boat. It just seemed like a job to him but nothing he loved to do.

We say at least 5 alligators up to 6 foot. They seemed small and they were not afraid of the people at all!! They do love marshmallows which was new to me! We saw a few turtles and saw a family of boars! I would recommend and take any swamp tour on your stay in New Orleans.

We booked our morning swamp tour online, pretty easy to do. Upon arrival, we parked in their free lot, checked-in at their front office/gift shop, and waited on the patio for our tour time. Led by Captain Chris, we ventured out to see gators, egrets, and "trash pandas" (the pigs/boars(?) didn't want to cooperate that day), while taking in the lush, swampy landscape. Captain was engaging, fun, and knowledgeable, accommodating to all in our group, which included children and a bachelorette party (trying to explain gator sex with children present is no small feat!).
They didn't have a sale today. It was some kind of  bug flying around so me and my sister had to leave.

3-4 stars for Dawa our chef who was amazing!  I noticed that he performed many more table-side theatrics than the other chefs and was very meticulous about even the slicing of the meats.  I would recommend asking for him.  

The food itself was pretty standard and be forewarned that A LOT of butter is used so it's not a meal for the light of diet, although you can definitely ask for a lighter version.  I was happy with my Seafood Diablo udon, which came with plenty of shrimp, scallops and squid.  The squid was surprisingly very tender, which is very hard to achieve; most places overcook it.  The yakisoba was decent as well and the chicken teriyaki was very juicy and tender.  The portions are also pretty generous and definitely get the fried rice instead of the steamed.  

We came in a party of 2 and had our own table, which was really nice, as a lot of places will make you share with other diners.  Our hostess was pretty stand-offish with an entitled air of ennui, which was rather annoying, although our actual waitress was great.

I had not been to a benihana on over 20 years - and back then ist was teppanyaki only (no real sushi). Ah, the '80's - and we all owe a debt to Rocky Ayoki.

The sushi selections have improved a bit - although fish selections are limited and the Hamachi Hand Roll I had was sub-par.  (Tamago was froze - for $2.75 a piece).  Prices were too high for that sort of mediocrity.

Service was harried - we were seated on a rainy Sunday at 7 PM in the bar area, albeit with our picky 7 year old who did not care for her $3.90 Strawberry Lemonade.  (She had water instead.)

Edamame was boiled within an inch of its life.

My MIL had a tasty steak teriyaki - surprisingly yhe best of the lot.
Oh and for $4.00 a single round blob of chocolate Hagen Daaz was unceremoniously plopped in a dished and thrown at my child.

Not in a hurry to return.

I'm from Milwaukee, and we pride ourselves on serving up the best frozen custard in all the land. (WI readers should probably stop here to avoid massive outrage)

Ted Drewes is amazing - it's as good as anything I've had anywhere else and if I'm going to be honest it may be a wee (just a wee) bit better than what I get at home. That was hard for me to admit but Yelp is about honesty, right? 

I had a small s'mores sundae and everything about it was perfect: the custard was perfectly creamy and not overly sweet. The chocolate was luscious, melty milk chocolate and applied in just the right amount. Add in some marshmallow goo & graham cracker bits.....wow. Everything was in perfect proportion - not too much of any one thing. High quality ingredients and friendly staff complete the picture. 

I'm told that Ted's has lines even in the dead of winter & I can see why. I had half a mind to get right back in line myself and order a second helping.
This is a hometown staple and I have to visit every time I come back.  Always good - it's never, ever changed.

A solid star at least for ambience and refusing to re-tool, redecorate, update or generally cave in to trends over the years.  This is the quintessential "if it ain't broke, don't fix it" food service establishment in St. Louis and an essential Route 66 stop. 

As long as I can remember, you could drive by Ted Drewes on any hot St. Louis summer night and see 60 or so people lined up at their 6 or 8 windows.  Sometimes the lines go almost into the street (and it's pretty busy).  For some locals being hit by a car while in line at Ted Drewes the perfect way to go.

Yes, it's all about nostalgia, but the frozen custard is also pretty good.  Okay, maybe Culver's is as good and a bit cheaper, but it's not a St. Lous thing like a visit to Ted's.  You also have to give kudo's for making this great dish before it was cool (no pun intended).

We went last week again after checking out the great St. Louis Hills Christmas lights.  In wintertime they sell trees (don't know anythying about this - we use fakes), but the ice cream is still for sale.  Seeing those ultra charming St. Louis Hills homes, Christmas lights and Ted Drewes all in one evening?  Well, it doesn't get more St. Louis than that.  

I hope you're not still wondering whether to go.  We're talking maybe ten bucks here - just do it.  I was going to give it just four stars, but I could never show my face before the Arch again if I did.

WOOOOOOOOO

When I drove cross country from California to Illinois to go to college, I drove an extra 250 miles to go through St.Louis (my hometown) so that I could stop at Ted Drewes.
It's that good.

This place is great!!! Lots of variety and so hard to choose what to get. I ended up getting the Strawberry Shortcake w/ caramel and nuts on top! Oooh, it was so delicious. My husband got the Christy which is a brownie w/ custard and chocolate and caramel....I think, he said it was pretty good too, but mine was better :). The kids also loved it.

Thank god our road trip took us through St. Louis just for the Ted Drewes alone!

Located in kind of a suburban area, this location is easy to get to and has ample parking. Staff is nice and prices are fair.

My oreo concrete was delicious. The perfect combination of creamy, cool, refreshing, and tasty on a hot day.

This place is an institution, and worth visiting, and very yummy.  What is a concrete?  It's frozen custard, and they mix the toppings within like a blizzard.  Go for one of the multiple signature creations or make your own.  This place gets crowded on certain nights as it is quite famous.

I wish I had the time and the ware-withall to have eaten this immediately instead of hitting the road to make time.  That one is my fault entirely. However, we did not.

We got to Ted Drewes on a Tuesday morning, 10 minutes before it opened, and we were the 8 and 9th people in line.  In June.  Yes, it's that popular.  By the time it openned, there were about 20 people in line, and about half of the people seemed to be first timers, because half went to the back of the line, and the other half asked "Why we weren't just getting our ice cream already," or "Why do you say I'm not in line? I just decided to stand next to the window and ignore the other 20 people who look like they're patiently waiting..."

By the time I was trying to plow through my blueberry concrete, it was about 10-15 minutes after it was put into the cup. The top was melted like crazy, and was a complete mess. The blueberries were a great addition though, and the flavor was solid.  I just really wanted to try the texture of the concrete as it was intended.  I thought it was a little on the sweet side, but I also know that was in part due to me waiting on eating it.  If I didn't wait 5 minutes, I am 80% sure that the sweetness would have been spot on.

My husband got the new pomegranate concrete, and well, he pretty much drank his.  It did taste good, but I wish I wish I wish we ate them faster.

Oh, Ted Drewes--want to touch the heiney!

I am not from St. Louis.  My husband is.  Ted Drewes on the ol' Route 66 is perhaps the first place we stopped on my first trip to The Lou, which just happened to be in the dead of winter.  Why, in the dead of winter with a parking lot full of Christmas trees, were there loads of people in line for more coldness?  Why?  Because it is damn amazing, that's why.  And really freakin' fast.  

Don't let the line frighten or deter you, 'cause it's just one short wait before creamy dairyland bliss.  My first concrete (basically a blizzard, but with better chunks and handed to you upside down to demonstrate its concrete-ity) had real peach slices swirled through the vanilla custard and is tied for my favorite concrete with the TeDad's--local St. Louis oatmeal cookies are mixed into that tasty treat.

I love that the place runs like a well-oiled machine by teenagers working towards a Ted Drewes-sponsored college scholarship and that you can buy cartons of the stuff for your own enjoyment--we even had some at our rehearsal dinner!  Even better, they'll pack a pile of frozen custard with dry ice so it survives the trip from STL to Chicago.

Yeah, I know STLians are sort of fanatical about Ted Drewes (but that's sort of normal from what I can tell, because they're basically fanatical about anything STL in general), but this is not unfounded loyalty and love.  I used to say that a trip to STL was wasted unless we visited my frozen custard heaven... now my love/hate relationship with lactose limits the visits I can handle.  Even with the belly aches, though, every trip to Ted Drewes is so worth it.

*Edit* 2/5/08

How dare you, Ted Drewes.  I move to St. Louis in the dour month of January and you're CLOSED?  WHAT???  And now it's February and you're STILL CLOSED?  Geez, if I'd known better, I woulda stayed in Chicago til Spring!  Bah.

This is the best concrete joint in the world, nay, universe! From standard concrete flavors (chocolate chip, strawberry, chocolate, vanilla, etc.) to The Christy (a giant brownie sundae) you really can't go wrong with anything you order. My personal favorite is ordering a vanilla concrete in a Cardinals Cap with Reese's Peanut Butter Cups on top, but the toppings list is endless so, don't feel pressured to copy my order. In the summer the lines will be around the block, but that's part of the experience so bring your dogs, your kids, your friends and make an experience out of it! During the Christmas season they sell Christmas Trees and Concretes, but will close shortly after until about April. An absolute MUST-DO in Saint Louis, so don't miss out!

I have to go here every time I am in St. Louis.  My favorite is the Dutchmen's Delight.  It's custard with hot fudge, caramel sauce, whipped cream, almonds and butterscotch.  Yummy!

This used to be a tiny shack in the middle of a parking lot.  Now it's a medium size shack in a parking lot.  No restroom, but there is water on the side of the building if you need a drink.

There's plenty to choose from on the menu - many kinds of custard, sundaes, banana splits, etc.  The line gets long after a ball game or on a hot summer night, but they move VERY quickly to get your order.  If you want to get it to go and have to drive awhile, they wil give you dry ice.

Frozen custard was another must have while visiting Saint Louis, and Ted Drewes was the obvious choice. It seems like the kind of place where there will be a perpetual line at any time of day, but luckily there are lots of windows and the lines move quick!

I ordered a "concrete" with cookie dough and peanut butter cups and it was delicious!  A quick google search told me that the difference between frozen custard and ice cream is the addition of egg yolks to custard. It definitely didn't taste eggy, but it did taste different than regular ice cream. A good different!

Some of the servers were flipping the ice cream cups upside down before handing it to the customers, hence the name concrete...what a trick! :)

Tried both the turtle and All Shook Up... The former is packed with nuts and the latter is wonderfully packed with ripe banana... Get some, but due to the extreme richness, order a size smaller if you want your pants to still fit...

Insanely good! This is the first time I've ever been in St. Louis and Yelp helped me find this gem! I'm so happy that I found Ted Drewes because BOY IT WAS GOOD! My dad who normally eats insanely healthy had to have one of their concretes! I had "The Christy" and it was absolutely delicious! It had hot fudge, caramel and brownie mixed together as a concrete. It was so good! The brownie was soft and fudgy and the custard was very creamy and flavorful. 

If you're in St. Louis, you need to stop here asap!

Coming straight from Cecil Whittaker's I was worried about having enough room. Luckily the large s'more concrete just filled in the gaps nicely! Still jonesing for more of that wonder-substance! Pulling in, the place looked like a zoo, but the line was extremely fast. So don't be scared if that's what you see.

For my recent trip to St. Louis, Ted Drewes was on my list of places to stop by even though it was freezing outside without a bit of sunshine. My friends and I originally went to the other location because it was closer to where we were. But to our disappointment, the other location was closed and it told us to go to this location, which was about a 10-15 minute drive, depending on traffic. We got there and saw that Ted Drewes is a historic tourist spot to visit on Route 66 so we knew we were in for a real treat!

The menu can be overwhelming especially since I wanted to try everything. With the help of the lady taking my order, I narrowed down my choices and ordered the fox treat. And it was amazing. I really enjoyed the fresh fruits in my sundae but I think I wouldn't get the fudge next time because it became a bit too sweet towards the end.

My friends and I ran into a local as we were leaving and she said that this place is amazing and she has been going here once a month for as long as she can remember! This place is definitely a must see if you are visiting STL!

I had big plans to get homemade ice cream at Crown Candy Kitchen, but never found the time. But through research, I heard that Ted Drewes was another must try in St. Louis and at the recommendation from my Forest Park friends, I headed there.

It was packed! And the people didn't stop coming. I had to park like two streets over, on some curb illegally, walk through and alley to get here.  I worked my way through one of the lines, only to see twice as many people filling in behind me. It goes fast, don't worry!

I asked around to figure out what to get and it was determined a concrete (much like a blizzard or blast) would be the best experience. I got the Fox Treat (fudge, raspberry and macadamia nuts). There is no pictured evidence of this treat because I got stuck in a traffic on my way to my hotel and it didn't last long. However, it was delicious. Ted Drewe's serves frozen custard and to me it was extra sweet.  Too sweet. Next time I'll probably stick with something more simple so I can get the true taste of the custard.  

Oh, one other note.  The portions are HUGE. I think I ordered a small or medium or something. Whatever size I got I was shocked and asked if they got my order wrong. Nope! So, personally, I feel there is no need to splurge if you're feeling extra hungry. Pretty sure a small would have suit me just fine.

On my first visit to St. Louis, my bf took me to Ted Drewes. He grew up eating their custards and he insisted that I give them a try. I've always been a fan of frozen yogurt and have never truly indulged in custard. 

As popular as this place is, I expected sort of like an ice cream parlor where you could sit down and enjoy your treat. Well we pull up to Ted Drewes and it is a tiny shop in the middle of a "parking lot." The shop has a window where you place your order. 

We got the oreo concrete. It was silky smooth and ohhh sooo indulgent. I kind of felt guilty eating this but still enjoyed it. 

Bottom line- this business is a St. Louis legacy and you must try their custards if you happen to be in town.

Yum yum yum! I've only been twice, but it's enough to stick in my memory and cause me to argue for a visit every time I'm in town. Culpepper's for dinner, then Ted Drewes for dessert - I'm a happy man. I've never seen them without lines 6 deep, and that's with 6 or 8 windows operating! Still, they move quickly and prices are amazingly good, so it's definitely worth it. Ted Drewes has been a local fixture for so long that you'll see 3 generations of people hanging around eating and chatting - there's no seating, so it's either standing or sitting on the hood/trunk of your car. (With that many people milling around parking can be challenging.)

The frozen custard itself is amazing. Delicious and as smooth and rich as the highest-quality ice cream you've ever had. A large range of excellent toppings and mix-ins are available. I thought my tart cherry and hot fudge ("Cardinal Sin") was good until I tried my dad's raspberry; if he hadn't turned his back on me and walked away (!) after my one bite, he might not have gotten any more. ("We could share it, we could!") I guess ol' Dad's not so dumb after all...

Famous for its frozen custard.  An icon in St. Louis.  Invented the concrete.  Never had a concrete in my life till today 9/28/2014.  I ordered a hot fudge concrete and it was huge and delicious down to the last bite.  I really don't have too much to add to the hundreds of reviews other than it deserves its reputation as an icon.

What's to say about Ted Drewes? It's delicious. I like the Cindermint concrete and the Johnny Rabbit concrete. On Friday  night I had the Johnny Rabbit (cherries and chocolate chips). Yum! I took my grandmother and she had the Terramizzou. She was thrilled and hadn't been there in years. Go there. It's delicious!

In town for a few days a friend who lives in the area wanted to show us all things St. Louis. Of course he drove us by the arch and Forest Park, told us what pork steak is and intrigued us with toasted ravioli. Then he introduced us to Frozen Custard. Boy am I glad he did because it was deeeeeelicious. 

I'm a fan of frozen yogurt, ice cream and gelato so I didn't know where frozen custard would fall on the spectrum. I'd have to say it's a lot lighter in taste than ice cream and maybe even lighter that FroYo. 

With sundaes, malts, shakes, floats and concretes to choose from I had to go with the concrete. My friend compared it to a DQ blizzard and I'd say that's an accurate analogy. 

There were many different flavor choices and combinations to choose from. Thank goodness they had a few combination suggestions. I had the turtle (hot fudge, caramel and pecans) and it was so good. I went with the smallest size (a micro) but wished I had gone bigger b/c I was so sad when it was done. I tasted my friend's lemon crumb and it was sooooo good too. 

I don't come to St. Louis often but the next time I do I'll definitely be back to Ted Drewes.

Hot ol' afternoon, kids in shorts, pretty girl on my arm. This is summer. 

We don't have frozen custard where I come from. Straight up do not even know what it is. God it's good. It tastes like America, and freedom, and 1956. Sitting on a bench with butterscotch custard melting way too fast down my arm made me all kinds of nostalgic and I have no idea why. Like a kid without a care in the world and my whole life ahead of me. I'd go again just for that.

Frozen custard = the fountain of youth.
Closed as of 1/3/13. If you bought a Groupon you can redeem it at Marhaba across the bridge in Lambertville

I would give this 6 stars if I could. Where to begin?

The BRUNCH is off the hook, same price as Jeannine's but you're eating in an art museum with French tapestries, elegant flatware, beauty in every corner of the room. 

I don't know how ANYONE could give this less than 5 stars. Now, at dinner it's apparently pricey. Duh. This is a fine dining institution in Santa Barbara and it's French with a star LA chef and the owners spared no expense in the remodeling of the casual, not divey but not nice, State and A which managed to stay in business a couple decades in spite of the subpar food. 

It turns out the owners have grown daughters in NYC and I have so enjoyed my afternoon here. My iPhone 5 makes a hotspot so I'm blogging before I meet a friend at 4 and swim to work off the potato daphinois--don't ask about the fat content--a sinful tower of thinly sliced potatoes with cheese and oil and all manner of terrible things which taste wonderful. 

My scramble--a bargain at 12.95--included perfect carmelized onions, roasted peppers, spinach and a hint of goat cheese--and I will dream of this till my next brunch here after Chicago/Michigan trip. 

After 5 cups of coffee to wake me up from horrible asthmatic night, I had a glass of the Ballard Pinot for dessert Nice but no better than the cheaper--9/glass--Kenwood Cab which I think is quite a respectable Cab for the money. 

The coffee is good but if you're like my father who, due to his time in the military, requires coffee which scalds the tongue, you will need to pull a Dad and ask them to nuke it in the "radar oven." It's not hot but I don't really care as it tasted good and did the trick: that is, it enabled me to have two glasses of wine after a miserable night of wheezing, hacking and blowing my nose. 

I cannot say enough for Maggie's and am so happy it's here in SB. I will come before my next show at the Granada for dinner at the bar. I have a subscription (see Yelp) and come alone.

PS I haven't eaten here at dinner yet but every single person who brought me food or booze was fabulous and I got to chat at length with the spectacular, smart owner with whom it turns out I have quite a bit culturally in common. I have no clue what people are talking about re service. It's not crowded but it's not empty and they have taken magnificent care of me.

This is one of those odd restaurant locations that can throw you off because it's inside a odd business location, the only other one like it I know is the Barn at Lucerne ... when you walk in with various businesses located there and then there is "patio" with a businesses meet up type thing and you go this way to enter the restaurant, it's just odd, with an older décor feeling.  Not sure what to expect I was then actually surprised the food was as good as it was.   You do have that Italian service that goes with it, not anything high end, more like being served by your family or neighborhood friends but good service regardless.

On our plates this night were the house salad (pretty good) Tilapia (very good), the strip steak (pretty good) and the tiramisu (very good, which is hard to do with tiramisu).    

Overall it's closer to a 3 than it would be a 5 so it was a decent experience and not outstanding but I am glad I had the chance to try.

Absolutely love this place. Unfortunately I only seem to get there for lunch, so I haven't been able to enjoy their wine selection, but I have to tell ya. There isn't much better then this place. 

The Spinach salad is unbelievable and the tortellini is the best I have ever eaten. All tortellini, in my mind, is compared to the taste of this place. 

It also has a very unique atmosphere sitting in an atrium like setting watching the older looking elevator run up and down the wall.

It's no secret that I am an enormous fan of BDubs and wish there was one around the corner for us. Seeing as how that's not happening any time soon, a visit every now and then is in order. 

This fits the chain well - big space inside, plenty of TVs to watch the NUMEROUS sporting events going on. Our server was terrific, food came out fast. Fried pickes because they are awesome, grilled chicken wrap with parmesean garlic sauce, because that's the jam right there. 

Great location if you're out in Downington - it's right off 30, across from the movie theater, BJs, DSW, etc. It's a very family friendly restaurant.

Fantastic new store! Huge and bright, and so much great stuff! There's a deli with freshly made meal options to go (lasagna, salads, sides, etc), gorgeous desserts, a meat department with meat already marinating, and so many more aisles filled with other food.  Bulk bins as well with lots of beans/lentils. They have frozen meat and fish, and the prices looked reasonable to me.

The produce section seemed kind of small when you take into account how big this store is, and the actually didn't have something I was looking for.

This is overall a great organic grocery store!

We found them on Groupon but honestly this was one of the best tours we did on this trip. Their office are located near Armstrong Park so you can walk around there if you have some time to kill before or after the tour.

Their office is also shared with a bar, so treat yourself to a Hurricane or two if you want to! Just don't bring it into the cemetery later. 

We did the St. Louis Cemetery #1 tour. I don't recall what our guide's name was, but she was lovely and had a lot of history to share with us. It was well paced so it's good for young and old alike.

I really want to like Crazy Sushi, especially because so many people are giving them good reviews, but I went back last weekend to use a groupon and I still wasn't impressed.  We ordered a couple specialty rolls and a basic roll.  It just seemed like the rolls were all filler and very little fish.  My friend commented on this as well.  It's a cool place and the presentation is really nice, but I'd rather have a basic presentation and better sushi.

I loveddd this place! We went here with a big group - like 8 people on a Saturday around 7pm. We didn't have a reservation but they were able to quickly seat us. I had passed this place a million times walking through rittenhouse and I always thought it was a sketchy chinese/sushi place but it's actually really pretty inside. The main eating area is on the second floor but they have a handicap elevator thing so you can get up there if you are in a wheelchair or something. As a vegetarian, there are not too many things I can have but they had a few rolls, which was great! They have "crazy" presentations and it was interesting watching the chefs put them together. It's byob so if you want to drink you have to bring it. The only reason I removed a star is that they forgot my seaweed salad.

Came with a friend who had been here before and wanted to take me out to celebrate a successful first day at my new job, and Crazy Sushi was the perfect place! Great service, great ambiance, and more importantly, great sushi! We got a few rolls to share between the two of us (all vegetarian rolls- fried banana, pumpkin, and sweet potato) and I got a bagel roll (salmon and cream cheese, lightly fried on the outside) for myself.  The way they plate and present their sushi is the most elaborate and creative I've ever seen anywhere! Looking forward to my next visit!

I deducted one star because the service was not great. Our waiter wasn't friendly at all. The first question was "soup or salad ". I wanted to order appetizer and lunch special, but he assumed we were having lunch. Seaweed salad was really good. Shiomay was small but good. The sashimi was fresh. Banzai roll was great and unique. Raw salmon and white fish with avocado and fish egg wrapped in cucumber with some sweet sauce. Perfect for those who is looking for no-rice roll. Salad dressing was more like carrot purée.

Above-average BYOB sushi place for Philly. Things that were better than expected: menus, decor, overall ambiance.  Not so great things: some of the special rolls only have 5 pieces, while the regular rolls have 8 pieces. So you are better off getting the regular rolls even though it might be tempting to try some of the more interesting ones. Just beware, they come in varying sizes, so you may want to ask about how many pieces are included in each!

Well, hello there Crazy Sushi. thank you for fulfilling your duty as a sushi restaurant and offering me delicious, fresh and affordable meals. 

As I explore Philadelphia and use yelp for guidance, I have been let down quite a few times. Crazy sushi however was an extremely awesome surprise. Sushi is one of those things that if you do wrong, there's no fixing and it leaves reminders like "you sure you want have sushi again, it was so gross last time". 

For lunch they offer a ton of specials! From bento boxes to roll specials. You can get two rolls with a soup or salad for 8 bucks or you can get three rolls with soup or salad for 12 bucks. Do yourself the favor and get three rolls. The sushi is always extremely fresh!!! The staff is beyond nice and welcoming. 

I wish they can open a location next to me in jersey. But in the meantime I'll continue to enjoy my lunch here. Thank you, crazy sushi- I appreciate that you did not ruin sushi for me.

Good food, though I felt like the portions were smaller than I was expecting for the price. I'm surprised that other Yelper's rated this two dollar signs. I also wish they'd had gluten free soy sauce. Other than that, there is really nothing to complain about and I still was able to enjoy my meal.

I've been to Crazy Sushi quite a few times (most recently about a month ago with my SO), and I have to say that the quality has gone down. 

They specialize in novel rolls (hence the name), and while they might be good (I never get them so I can't say) as a sushi spot you have to do traditional rolls right as well. Unfortunately, crazy sushi does not do that. The fish isn't super fresh and the rice-fish-seaweed ratio is off. It's not worse than most other sushi spots in the city, but it's not better either.

Found it on Yelp (because you do NOT eat sushi in a new city without reading anything), and have to agree: this is solidly four stars.  The sushi is slightly overpriced (compared to the West Coast anyway) but fresher than I expected, and the presentation is really superb.

I went here for lunch the other day with a buddy of mine off my recomondation via yelp of course....lol.  Anyways, it looked like it was gonna be a good find.   We pull up and it just so happens theres a parking lot about a 100 feet from the place.   So that was convenient.  We got there right at 11:30am the time they were supposed to open...There was no sign of life inside and there was 2 Asian dudes sitting at the front door waiting to get in as well.  So, I took a wild guess and asked them if they worked there, and they said YES....Lucky guess I suppose....I asked where the people were with the key and they said 5 mins away in a cab....Um okay, so 15 mins later a carload of chefs and waiters arrive and we go in....I was a little pissed, but figured no biggie, lets give this spot a try bc I saw all the great reviews and pictures on yelp.   

Well I'm glad I DID!!!!   We get inside and the place was very clean and pretty cool looking....Our waiter was very attentive especially I think bc he was 1 of the dudes outside waiting with us, lol...However, they have a GREAT menu with a lot of options...I had some eel sushi which was very good and my buddy had some assortment platter thing...Now, the best thing though was the "One night stand roll" I ordered!!!!!   IT WAS FREAKING SLAMMING!!!!!!!!!!   It had salmon and tuna wrapped around spicy, crunchy crab!!!!!    NO RICE!!!!!!   Banging!!!!!    All the food was well worth all the BS I went through up till this point.   Also, the presentation of the food when it comes out is awesome too, make sure you have ur camera!!!!  I'd definitely go back, but I'd just give them a little more time to get to work  next time.  When we left it was around 12:30pm and the place was slammed too, so that's a good sign....

This place is totally decent. I've been here once for dine-in and once for take-out. No complaints. 

What you really need to know is this: Crazy Sushi is currently offering a "two rolls for $6/three rolls for $8" opening special. Crazy sushi, crazy cheap. 

When I dined in on the first day they were in business, this special was not offered. Don't know when it will end, either. Get it while you can.

Really love the green chile burger and SUPER happy Blake's came to Tucson.  While I do live on the southeast side, I have no problem driving thirty minutes to get one of their burgers.  The drive through is pretty busy, but they move people through fast.  Welcome to Tucson Blake's!

I have driven PAST Blake's in Deming, NM on my way out of Hatch so many times and always thought to myself, "Huh, I really should try them out." But I never do because I just want to get home to Tucson and to be honest, 9 times out of 10 I just put a Sparky's green chile cheeseburger in my belly so I wasn't hungry. When Blake's came to Tucson, I was really excited!!!

Don't believe the hype. The green chile cheeseburger at Blake's is a mediocre burger overall with the saving grace being the green chile. The green chile is delicious but not very hot, at least for my taste but that's not where I find fault with this burger. The actual burger is greasy and just a whatever burger. Mine was thrown together so sloppily that I had more onions and tomatoes off the bun than on it. I literally had to put my burger back together before I could eat it. And then the grease started dripping off my hands. Honestly, I would compare the "burger" part of my sandwich to any old fast food place but priced much higher. We also had seasoned fries which were good and onion rings which were not. The size of the order of onion rings for the price was NOT a bargain at all.

So I'm glad I finally tried Blake's but I really don't think I'll be back. Especially when the green chile double cheeseburger I had at Whataburger was actually better but then again, my judgement on that one may have been clouded by a hangover.

Culver's is what it is.   Kind of the red-headed step/lovechild of a fast food burger joint and an ice cream shoppe.   If you're really craving a quick burger, this is not the first place that would come to mind.   If you're looking for ice cream (excuse me....custard), this is not the first place that would come to mind.   However, if you're looking for a place that offers fast food burgers and custard, then this is one of the few places that can do it.   Average burgers and average custard.

This isn't a criticism of this particular location, but of all Culver's in general...$1.20 extra for nuts on a sundae, but the candy toppings are free?

Due to the prime location right off 465 on 67/Kentucky Avenue, it's usually pretty busy.

Fast, friendly, and efficient.  They always greet you at the door, which is nice.  The food and the ice cream treats are made to order.  I had a burger on  sourdough bread.  I thought the bread had a slightly odd taste to it, even for sourdough.  But my burger was good.  For dessert, I got a concrete mixer made with the flavor of the day (S'mores), Oreos, and caramel.  It was really good.  Packed with good stuff. 

I would come back here again.  I just wouldn't order the sourdough melt.

(3.5) ~ good overall food & service.  Note: It's mainly for Take-Out, but there are a few tables inside.

MENU:
** Mango Lassi = (4) very good
** Lamb Vindaloo = (4) very good & spicy
* Onion Kulcha = (3.5) good
* Raita = (3.25) pretty good, but watery...
* Water(tap) = (3) ok, but needed to be filtered, to remove the chlorine taste, etc.
***Kulfi(dessert) = Next time....

We ordered take out from here the other night.  We were pretty excited about take out sushi in the area so we gave it a shot.  The menu wasn't that impressive, kind of a boring selection, but we ordered a few rolls and the staff was friendly and the delivery prompt.  The rolls themselves weren't anything exciting, but were tasty enough.  We'll probably order from here again when we're too lazy to go out and get sushi.

Eeeeeeek!

I withdraw my previous review!  The food was okay but I didn't know I was risking my health by eating here :-(

http://edmontonjournal.com/news/local-news/downtown-chinese-restaurant-fined-42000-for-public-health-violations

http://www.nationalpost.com/m/wp/blog.html?b=news.nationalpost.com/news/canada/edmonton-chinese-restaurant-fined-42000-after-cockroaches-filthy-kitchen-discovered-as-well-inspectors-noted-that-several-deficient-kitchen-utensils-that-had-been-thrown-out-at-an-earlier-inspec

So I'm pretty torn about this place generally. For one I know that the health and safety record of this place isn't amazing. For another I've had really varied experiences here. That said whenever I've been here, it has been for special events with a group of people and in general these events have been really quite great and/or quite delicious.
I love the really varied food options that they serve here and just how well they can handle large group events. I like the interior decor and the dishes. The service can be pretty variable. This location is in a really run-down mall and the area itself doesn't feel all that safe or vibrant after dark, but I don't avoid this area especially when I have an excuse to visit for some delicious Chinese food. Usually I've been there for 10 course meals which are always way more food than I need to be eating but it's a sometimes treat that is worth having. So there's that! :) 
I don't avoid this place. I don't seek it out. I think the food is generally really delicious, but I know that the service is middling. I've had better. I've had worse. And usually when I finish a meal here, I'm pretty darn full and happy. But I guess a lot of that is the fact that I'm usually here with a group for a 10 course meal. And I will admit that the owners are pretty awesome when it comes to handling groups and making our groups feel welcome.

Dynasty Century Palace where have you been all my life?!?  I have finally found my go to Dim Sum for downtown Edmonton.

Came yesterday and was pleasantly surprised by the quality of the food.  Brought a coworker for a lunch date and was BLOWN away by the hospitality, quality, and value!

As mentioned by other Yelpers, their price points are on the lower end mostly in the $3.50-$4 range with a few items higher ( ex. fried shrimp dumplings and sticky rice were in the $5-$6 range).  

And the kicker, the curried calamari was the B-E-S-T I have ever had at Dim Sum!  It was tender, delicious, and full of flavour; I would have liked a spoon served with it so I could get to all the sauce for my sticky rice without looking like a cave woman but I dove in anyway!

The egg tarts had just come out of the oven and were divine, also among the best I've had at Dim Sum.

The sticky rice comes in slightly smaller banana leaf wrapped parcels than I'm used to but an order comes with 3 rather than 2.  I don't thirecall any baby shrimp in them which would definitely make my husband happy if I can get him out here.

My dining partner wasn't as comfortable with chopsticks and we had to ask a couple times to get her a fork but otherwise the staff came back and checked on us frequently, filled our water, filled our tea, and asked if we liked the selections they had suggested. 

The dining room itself is quite large and open - I imagine it can get kind of loud in there but it was perfect yesterday.  We popped in about 1130 and had food on our table before we could get our jackets off.

We ordered WAY more items than we could finish and our total was still only just shy of $34 before tip.  Next time, I've got to try the noodle wrapped beef balls!  If you have faves here, send me a recommendation please :-)

Dynasty Century Palace, you have made a fan out of me!

P.S. Dim Sum/China Town newbies, this restaurant is located upstairs above the strip mall at the end of 97th street (south tip) before you hit the underpass to the courthouse/Brownlee Building area.  Free parking in back, just be sure to read the details of when/where/how long you can park there before getting ticketed

What do you go to TCBY for? Yogurt... delicious, moderately healthy, tasty yogurt at an affordable price. And for that they absolutely deliver! I give them 4-stars. Also, it's SO CRAZY AFFORDABLE compared to some of the self-serve yogurt places in the valley. Trust me, you get more bang for your buck at TCBY. With daily specials, you just can't go wrong.

Food: They have hand-scooped yogurt and sorbets, soft serve yogurt and sorbets, tons of toppings to pile on top, and cartons of yogurt as well as yogurt cakes. You just can't beat it! The cake batter soft serve is great. Pralines and Cream and Strawberries and Cream hand scooped flavors don't even taste like yogurt. They'd totally fool me! They're SO GOOD and creamy. 

Drinks: n/a

Atmosphere: It's very start and simple, but hey, it's a yogurt shop. They do have benches outside and a drive-thru. I feel like they cover all the bases.

Service: Super sweet and friendly. It's not a 5-star restaurant... it's almost always kids who work there who are earning a couple extra bucks. This is most likely their first job. Give them credit, they do a great and superb job!

Happy Hour Offerings: While they don't have happy hour, they do have daily specials! Make sure to check the sign posted out front for the deal of the day!

Healthy Hack: Wanting a little bit of a treat? Try a dairy-free sorbet to cut calories or go for a kid's size. 

Tips: n/a

We decided to make Zeppoli our go to destination with a couple of friends the Sunday before Christmas and I have to say, I am glad we did. Yes, we did have reservations and no we did not need to wait for a table. We arrived right on time and were immediately seated. Zeppoli's is great because it is also a BYOB, so we sat down and were given wine glasses immediately. The menu is small and precise. Our server was wonderful and before ordering we were told that this is traditional Cicillian cuisine and not standard Italian fare. 

We started out with the following apps: Panzanella Catania, Insalada Verde, and the Antipasto Siciliano. We were also given an order of Finocchi Salsiccia, Fennel Sausage, because they forgot to provide me with silverware. Both salads were good, citrusy and fresh. The anchovies that were on the Panzanella salad were ridiculously good and added a lightly salted note to the tomato and bread. The sausage was also delicious, it basically melted in your mouth and the rabe that was provided with the sausage gave it a great bitter element. But the star here was Antipasto. Good lord was that a good salad. I wish I could eat that dish every night. It was so wonderful. It has sharp provolone, marinated mushrooms, beans, salami, roasted red peppers and tomatoes and the list of awesomeness kept going. Probably the best Antipasto dish I have ever eaten.

For our Entrées the ladies each ordered the Taglietteli al Limone with prosciutto and I ordered the Taglietteli al Limone with bottarga as a small order and my buddy had the Pesto Trapanese. The Taglietteli was wonderful. It was like a flavor explosion in my mouth. Super citrusy and fresh and then you add in the bottarga and the dish just blew my mind because it went, citrusy, clean, fresh and oceany (Not sure if that is a word, but that is what it tasted like). Awesome dish! The pesto dish was ridiculous as well. My friend did let me try a bite; he was reluctant to do so. We also both had the Fisherman's Stew. It was good; the standout on this dish was the calamari. I guess that is how calamari is supposed to be cooked. It wasn't even close to rubbery, it was tender and basically melted in your mouth.

We did have room for desert and got the Zeppoli. They were wonderful, especially after you dipped them in the nutella. They came out fresh and hot. I definitely burned my mouth because I didn't want to wait to eat it.

Overall this was one of my favorite meals in 2012. I would come back to Zeppoli's every week if I could afford it, alas I cannot. However, next time we are looking for somewhere good to go near Cherry Hill, Zeppoli's will certainly be in the forefront of my mind.

Absolutely beyond the 'woohoo! as good as it gets!' 5 Yelp stars!  

Zeppoli blew me away with every course from start to finish!    Hands down - BEST MEAL OF THE YEAR 2016!  

The restaurant itself is small/intimate and no big deal of a decor; however, I loved all of their fresh plants and black & white photos of Italy.  

Bread - two varieties of each (3) with an incredible seasoned olive oil (comes w/ three olives).  

We shared two appetizers - a shrimp and bean one (three large and totally taste galore shrimp!) and an incredible pesto pasta one.  The sauces on each were insanely delcious!  Even the pasta itself was devine & that's my 'area of expertise!'  

I had a hard time choosing from the (small) menu b/c I do not eat (nor have ever tried, nor want to) rabbit, wasn't in the mood for chicken, was still teetering about the branzino and wasn't interested in the other menu items for differing reasons.

I did decide on the 'Fisherman's Stew.'  GREAT choice!!!!  It was absolutely AMAZING.  Clams, mussels, swordfish, shrimp and calamari in a broth that I made sure to get every possible lick of w/ my large spoon!  It also boasted really good cous cous (a touch more would've been nice).  Everything was cooked perfectly.  I cannot say enough about the broth!!   W  O  W  !!!!

Vince had a wonderfully delcious 'slab' of swordfish accompanied by an orange fennel salad (not up my alley) that he enjoyed tremendously.

We finished w/ a fabulously delectible dessert - pistachio and walnut semifreddo.  I have NEVER had a dessert such as this one before.  Every bite was absolutely luscious!  

They even put a sparkler atop for Vince's birthday!

I did not want this night or meal to end!  

I will & would reccommend 'Zeppoli' to everyone, especially those who are looking to impess someone for a special occasion. 

 TO DIE FOR!

This is a Pharmacy that goes above and beyond the regular customer service. All the   Pharmacists are very professional and helpful. They have taken their time with us and explain everything we may question.

The store manager Lisa, greets us as if we've known her for years ( I guess she has) and is genuinely warm. I'm so glad our health plan changed from Walgreens to CVS. Much better service and quality here.

This is my local Walgreens and they're very helpful here. Everyone from the pharmacist to the cashiers is always willing to help. If something rings up wrong they fix it immediately without the eye roll you get from most. The line for the pharmacy can get quite long during peak hours so I always try to avoid going here directly after work.

I rarely bother with reviews of local chain stores, but this location and the employee who assisted me deserves a positive mention. 

First of all, I found this store super tidy, clean and neat and everything is organized and easy to find.

I stopped in today for Passport photos and was assisted by Frank. This young man was so kind and patient. He helped direct me on "where to look" and how to position my head - in a nice way of course - for the best photo results. He even took the time to do another round of photos since the first set looked awful - I kept blinking and whatnot.

What's more, this thoughtful employee left his post to find me while I was shopping and let me select from one of two photos. Apparently customer satisfaction is a priority to Frank. What a fantastic experience. Please keep up the good work.

I started off the meal with a baby blossom.  it was good...but in the world of chain steakhouse onion blooms...this doesn't compare to Outback's.
